Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Survey and Analysis of the Angolan Herpetofauna
Award.AbstractNarration:
Angola is among the largest countries in Africa, and its landscapes vary from arid desert to equatorial rainforest. This landscape diversity results in high, but poorly documented, levels of biodiversity in many groups, including amphibians and reptiles. This project will increase understanding of the diversity and evolution of Angola's amphibians and reptiles by analyzing species' distributions, abundances, genetics, and anatomy. Based on these data, undocumented species will be identified, characterized and formally described. Two major hypotheses will be tested: whether arid-adapted species of S.W. Angola are descended from East African ancestors that migrated during periods of dry climate, and whether species restricted to the Angolan highlands are ancient descendants of formerly widespread ancestors. Researchers will also test how climate factors affect the degree to which malaria-causing parasites specialize on particular lizard species. This project will also train students in field and laboratory methods, as well as data dissemination and analysis. Public outreach efforts will include development of short video documentaries and English- and Portuguese-language guides to Angola's amphibians and reptiles.

Surveys of the Angolan herpetofauna will be informed by current knowledge gained from the less than 8,000 specimens that currently exist in museums worldwide. A total of six expeditions throughout Angola will be undertaken over a period of three years, with each focusing on a region identified as poorly sampled based on the provenance of extant museum specimens or as key sampling areas for addressing taxonomic problems. Specimens obtained in survey efforts will be subjected to collection and analysis of ecological, genetic, and morphological data. Molecular systematic analyses of the genetic data will identify cryptic species and targeted high-throughput sequencing will be used to test biogeographic hypotheses. Morphological data collection will include external morphological examination as well as high-resolution CT scanning to identify diagnostic internal anatomical features of species under study. Ecological niche modeling of species' ranges will be used to explore patterns of faunal turnover and identify conservation priorities. All biodiversity data generated in the course of the project, including point localities, DNA sequences, and CT scans, will be made available to the broader scientific community. Results of the research will be disseminated in numerous publications focused on taxonomic revision, biogeography, morphological diversity, and/or parasite evolutionary ecology of the Angolan herpetofauna.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project contributed significantly to our knowledge of the amphibian and reptile diversity of Angola, a sub-Saharan African country situated at the meeting point of arid southwestern Africa and the wet tropics of central Africa. By collecting throughout much of the western half of the country we were able to estimate the distribution of the herpetofauna and generate data about both genetic and morphological variation in Angola and in other regions in central and southern Africa. We discovered new species of frogs, snakes, and especially lizards, increasing the known diversity of the country. This project disseminated information through 38 peer-reviewed journal articles, 35 oral and poster presentations at conferences, and 229 IUCN red listing species accounts. These included descriptions of new species, phylogenetic analyses of many genera of amphibians and reptiles, surveys of the fauna of protected areas, and a review of the important herpetological collections housed in the poorly studied Museu do Dundo in northeastern Angola. We also synthesized all of the historical records and current systematic status of the amphibians and reptiles of Angola in a monographic atlas and contributed to the evaluation of the threats and conservation status of the lizards and snakes of Angola, as well as adjacent Namibia. Collectively, our studies emphasized the high level of endemism characterizing the Angolan Escarpment, identified previously unrecognized regional diversity within the arid zone of Angola and revealed historical connections to arid regions in the Horn of Africa, and demonstrated that Serra da Neve, an isolated mountain in the southwest, harbors a suite of unique species. Novel hypotheses of relationship clarified evolutionary relationships among many lineages, including some of the most diverse and species rich genera of geckos, skinks, lacertids and snakes in the region.

At Villanova University, this project supported training for two postdoctoral researchers, two undergraduate students, seven Master’s students, including four women – one from Angola, and one LGBTQ student. A doctoral student in Vairão, Portugal was also trained. Field work led by Villanova. generated preserved scientific specimens and associated tissue samples for >1,000 specimens of >110 species in >50 genera of amphibians and reptiles. All specimens have been deposited in the California Academy of Sciences (>600 specimens), the Florida Museum of Natural History (>300 specimens), with a representative collection provided to the Instituto Nacional da Biodiversidade e Áreas de Conservação (INBAC) in Luanda, Angola. DNA sequences and CT-scans (generated in conjunction with collaborating institutions the University of Michigan Dearborn and the University of Florida) have been made publicly available via the online repositories GenBank and MorphoSource, respectively. The project developed capacity of biodiversity scientists in Angola through training in field and laboratory research and made new distributional data available for applications in local conservation management.
